<!--[if lt IE 7]><style type="text/css">body{behavior:url("/w/skins/vector/csshover.min.htc")}</style><![endif]--></head>
<body class="mediawiki ltr sitedir-ltr ns-0 ns-subject page-Food skin-vector action-view vector-animateLayout">
		<div id="mw-page-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="mw-head-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="content" class="mw-body" role="main">
			<a id="top"></a>
			<div id="mw-js-message" style="display:none;"></div>
						<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><span dir="auto">Food</span></h1>
			<div id="bodyContent">
								<div id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
								<div id="contentSub"></div>
												<div id="jump-to-nav" class="mw-jump">
					Jump to:					<a href="#mw-navigation">navigation</a>, 					<a href="#p-search">search</a>
				</div>
				<div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr"><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:About&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:About (page does not exist)">Template:About</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Pp-semi-vandalism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Pp-semi-vandalism (page does not exist)">Template:Pp-semi-vandalism</a><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Pp-move-indef&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Pp-move-indef (page does not exist)">Template:Pp-move-indef</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Good_Food_Display_-_NCI_Visuals_Online.jpg" title="File:Good Food Display - NCI Visuals Online.jpg">File:Good Food Display - NCI Visuals Online.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Various foods</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Foods_(cropped).jpg" title="File:Foods (cropped).jpg">File:Foods (cropped).jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Foods from plant sources</div></div></div>
<p><b>Food</b> is any substance<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">[1]</a></sup> consumed to provide nutritional support for the body. It is usually of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Plant&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Plant (page does not exist)">plant</a> or <a href="/w/index.php?title=Animal&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Animal (page does not exist)">animal</a> origin, and contains essential <a href="/wiki/Nutrient" title="Nutrient">nutrients</a>, such as <a href="/wiki/Carbohydrate" title="Carbohydrate">carbohydrates</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fat" title="Fat">fats</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Protein_(nutrient)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Protein (nutrient) (page does not exist)">proteins</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vitamin" title="Vitamin">vitamins</a>, or <a href="/wiki/Mineral" title="Mineral">minerals</a>. The substance is <a href="/wiki/Ingestion" title="Ingestion">ingested</a> by an <a href="/w/index.php?title=Organism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Organism (page does not exist)">organism</a> and assimilated by the organism's <a href="/wiki/Cell_(biology)" title="Cell (biology)">cells</a> in an effort to produce <a href="/wiki/Energy" title="Energy">energy</a>, maintain life, or stimulate growth.
</p><p>Historically, people secured food through two methods: <a href="/wiki/Hunter-gatherer" title="Hunter-gatherer">hunting and gathering</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Agriculture" title="Agriculture">agriculture</a>. Today, most of the <a href="/wiki/Food_energy" title="Food energy">food energy</a> consumed by the <a href="/w/index.php?title=World_population&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="World population (page does not exist)">world population</a> is supplied by the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Food_industry&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Food industry (page does not exist)">food industry</a>.
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Food_safety&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Food safety (page does not exist)">Food safety</a> and <a href="/wiki/Food_security" title="Food security">food security</a> are monitored by agencies like the <a href="/w/index.php?title=International_Association_for_Food_Protection&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="International Association for Food Protection (page does not exist)">International Association for Food Protection</a>, <a href="/wiki/World_Resources_Institute" title="World Resources Institute">World Resources Institute</a>, <a href="/wiki/World_Food_Programme" title="World Food Programme">World Food Programme</a>, <a href="/wiki/Food_and_Agriculture_Organization" title="Food and Agriculture Organization">Food and Agriculture Organization</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=International_Food_Information_Council&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="International Food Information Council (page does not exist)">International Food Information Council</a>. They address issues such as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sustainability&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sustainability (page does not exist)">sustainability</a>, <a href="/wiki/Biological_diversity" title="Biological diversity" class="mw-redirect">biological diversity</a>, <a href="/wiki/Climate_change" title="Climate change">climate change</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nutritional_economics&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nutritional economics (page does not exist)">nutritional economics</a>, <a href="/wiki/Population_growth" title="Population growth">population growth</a>, <a href="/wiki/Water_supply" title="Water supply">water supply</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Food_security" title="Food security">access to food</a>.
</p><p>The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Right_to_food&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Right to food (page does not exist)">right to food</a> is a <a href="/wiki/Human_right" title="Human right" class="mw-redirect">human right</a> derived from the <a href="/wiki/International_Covenant_on_Economic,_Social_and_Cultural_Rights" title="International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights">International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights</a> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=ICESCR&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="ICESCR (page does not exist)">ICESCR</a>), recognizing the "right to an adequate standard of living, including adequate food," as well as the "fundamental right to be free from hunger."
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:TOC_limit&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:TOC limit (page does not exist)">Template:TOC limit</a>
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc"><div id="toctitle"><h2>Contents</h2></div>

</ul>
</div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Food_sources">Food sources</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Food_consumption.gif" title="File:Food consumption.gif">File:Food consumption.gif</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Global average daily <a href="/wiki/Calorie" title="Calorie">calorie</a> consumption</div></div></div>
<p>Most food has its origin in plants. Some food is obtained directly from plants; but even animals that are used as food sources are raised by feeding them food derived from plants. <a href="/wiki/Cereal" title="Cereal">Cereal</a> grain is a <a href="/wiki/Staple_food" title="Staple food">staple food</a> that provides more food energy worldwide than any other type of crop. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Maize&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Maize (page does not exist)">Maize</a>, <a href="/wiki/Wheat" title="Wheat">wheat</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Rice" title="Rice">rice</a> – in all of their varieties – account for 87% of all grain production worldwide.<sup id="cite_ref-prodstat_2-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-prodstat-2">[2]</a></sup>  Most of the grain that is produced worldwide is fed to livestock.
</p><p>Some foods not from animal or plant sources include various edible <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fungi&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fungi (page does not exist)">fungi</a>, especially <a href="/wiki/Mushroom" title="Mushroom">mushrooms</a>. Fungi and ambient <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bacteria&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bacteria (page does not exist)">bacteria</a> are used in the preparation of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fermentation_(food)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fermentation (food) (page does not exist)">fermented</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pickled" title="Pickled" class="mw-redirect">pickled</a> foods like <a href="/wiki/Baker%27s_yeast" title="Baker's yeast">leavened</a> <a href="/wiki/Bread" title="Bread">bread</a>, <a href="/wiki/Alcoholic_drinks" title="Alcoholic drinks" class="mw-redirect">alcoholic drinks</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cheese&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cheese (page does not exist)">cheese</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pickled_cucumber&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pickled cucumber (page does not exist)">pickles</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kombucha" title="Kombucha">kombucha</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Yogurt" title="Yogurt">yogurt</a>. Another example is <a href="/wiki/Blue-green_algae" title="Blue-green algae" class="mw-redirect">blue-green algae</a> such as <a href="/wiki/Spirulina_(dietary_supplement)" title="Spirulina (dietary supplement)">Spirulina</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">[3]</a></sup> Inorganic substances such as <a href="/wiki/Salt" title="Salt">salt</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sodium_bicarbonate" title="Sodium bicarbonate">baking soda</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Potassium_hydrogen_tartrate&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Potassium hydrogen tartrate (page does not exist)">cream of tartar</a> are used to preserve or chemically alter an ingredient.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Plants">Plants</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>Many plants or plant parts are eaten as food. There are around 2,000 plant species which are cultivated for food, and many have several distinct <a href="/wiki/Cultivar" title="Cultivar">cultivars</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">[4]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Seed" title="Seed">Seeds</a> of plants are a good source of food for animals, including humans, because they contain the nutrients necessary for the plant's initial growth, including many healthful fats, such as <a href="/wiki/Omega-3" title="Omega-3" class="mw-redirect">Omega fats</a>. In fact, the majority of food consumed by human beings are seed-based foods. Edible seeds include <a href="/wiki/Cereal" title="Cereal">cereals</a> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Maize&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Maize (page does not exist)">maize</a>, <a href="/wiki/Wheat" title="Wheat">wheat</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rice" title="Rice">rice</a>, <a href="/wiki/Et_cetera" title="Et cetera">et cetera</a>), <a href="/wiki/Legume" title="Legume">legumes</a> (<a href="/wiki/Bean" title="Bean">beans</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pea" title="Pea">peas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lentil" title="Lentil">lentils</a>, <a href="/wiki/Et_cetera" title="Et cetera">et cetera</a>), and <a href="/wiki/Nut_(fruit)" title="Nut (fruit)">nuts</a>. <a href="/wiki/Oilseed" title="Oilseed" class="mw-redirect">Oilseeds</a> are often pressed to produce rich oils - <a href="/wiki/Sunflower" title="Sunflower">sunflower</a>, <a href="/wiki/Flaxseed" title="Flaxseed" class="mw-redirect">flaxseed</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rapeseed" title="Rapeseed">rapeseed</a> (including <a href="/wiki/Canola_oil" title="Canola oil" class="mw-redirect">canola oil</a>), <a href="/wiki/Sesame" title="Sesame">sesame</a>, <a href="/wiki/Et_cetera" title="Et cetera">et cetera</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-McGee9_5-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-McGee9-5">[5]</a></sup>
</p><p>Seeds are typically high in <a href="/wiki/Unsaturated_fat" title="Unsaturated fat">unsaturated fats</a> and, in moderation, are considered a <a href="/wiki/Health_food" title="Health food">health food</a>, although not all seeds are edible. Large seeds, such as those from a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lemon&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lemon (page does not exist)">lemon</a>, pose a choking hazard, while seeds from <a href="/wiki/Apples" title="Apples" class="mw-redirect">apples</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cherries" title="Cherries" class="mw-redirect">cherries</a> contain a poison (<a href="/wiki/Cyanide" title="Cyanide">cyanide</a>).
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Fruit" title="Fruit">Fruits</a> are the ripened ovaries of plants, including the seeds within. Many plants have evolved fruits that are attractive as a food source to animals, so that animals will eat the fruits and <a href="/wiki/Excretion" title="Excretion">excrete</a> the seeds some distance away. Fruits, therefore, make up a significant part of the diets of most cultures. Some botanical fruits, such as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tomato&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tomato (page does not exist)">tomatoes</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pumpkin&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pumpkin (page does not exist)">pumpkins</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Eggplant" title="Eggplant">eggplants</a>, are eaten as vegetables.<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">[6]</a></sup> (For more information, see <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_fruits&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of fruits (page does not exist)">list of fruits</a>.)
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Vegetable&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Vegetable (page does not exist)">Vegetables</a> are a second type of plant matter that is commonly eaten as food. These include <a href="/w/index.php?title=Root_vegetable&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Root vegetable (page does not exist)">root vegetables</a> (<a href="/wiki/Potato" title="Potato">potatoes</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Carrot&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Carrot (page does not exist)">carrots</a>), bulbs (<a href="/wiki/Onion" title="Onion">onion</a> family), <a href="/wiki/Leaf_vegetable" title="Leaf vegetable">leaf vegetables</a> (<a href="/wiki/Spinach" title="Spinach">spinach</a> and <a href="/wiki/Lettuce" title="Lettuce">lettuce</a>), <a href="/wiki/Category:Stem_vegetables" title="Category:Stem vegetables">stem vegetables</a> (<a href="/wiki/Bamboo" title="Bamboo">bamboo</a> shoots and <a href="/wiki/Asparagus" title="Asparagus">asparagus</a>), and <a href="/wiki/Category:Inflorescence_vegetables" title="Category:Inflorescence vegetables">inflorescence vegetables</a> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Globe_artichoke&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Globe artichoke (page does not exist)">globe artichokes</a> and <a href="/wiki/Broccoli" title="Broccoli">broccoli</a> and other vegetables such as <a href="/wiki/Cabbage" title="Cabbage">cabbage</a> or <a href="/wiki/Cauliflower" title="Cauliflower">cauliflower</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">[7]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Animals">Animals</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Meatfoodgroup.jpg" title="File:Meatfoodgroup.jpg">File:Meatfoodgroup.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Various raw <a href="/wiki/Meat" title="Meat">meats</a></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>Animals are used as food either directly or indirectly by the products they produce. <a href="/wiki/Meat" title="Meat">Meat</a> is an example of a direct product taken from an animal, which comes from <a href="/w/index.php?title=Muscle&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Muscle (page does not exist)">muscle</a> systems or from <a href="/wiki/Organ_(anatomy)" title="Organ (anatomy)">organs</a>. Food products produced by animals include <a href="/wiki/Milk" title="Milk">milk</a> produced by <a href="/wiki/Mammary_glands" title="Mammary glands" class="mw-redirect">mammary glands</a>, which in many cultures is drunk or processed into <a href="/wiki/Dairy_product" title="Dairy product">dairy products</a> (cheese, <a href="/wiki/Butter" title="Butter">butter</a>, etc.). In addition, birds and other animals lay <a href="/w/index.php?title=Egg_(food)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Egg (food) (page does not exist)">eggs</a>, which are often eaten, and <a href="/wiki/Bee" title="Bee">bees</a> produce <a href="/wiki/Honey" title="Honey">honey</a>, a reduced <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nectar&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nectar (page does not exist)">nectar</a> from flowers, which is a popular sweetener in many cultures. Some cultures <a href="/w/index.php?title=Blood_as_food&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Blood as food (page does not exist)">consume blood</a>, sometimes in the form of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Blood_sausage&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Blood sausage (page does not exist)">blood sausage</a>, as a thickener for sauces, or in a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Curing_(food_preservation)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Curing (food preservation) (page does not exist)">cured</a>, <a href="/wiki/Salting_(food)" title="Salting (food)">salted</a> form for times of food scarcity, and others use <a href="/wiki/Blood" title="Blood">blood</a> in stews such as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jugging&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jugging (page does not exist)">jugged hare</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">[8]</a></sup>
</p><p>Some cultures and people do not consume meat or animal food products for cultural, dietary, health, ethical, or ideological reasons. <a href="/wiki/Vegetarian" title="Vegetarian" class="mw-redirect">Vegetarians</a> choose to forgo food from animal sources to varying degrees. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Vegan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Vegan (page does not exist)">Vegans</a> do not consume any foods that are or contain <a href="/wiki/Ingredients" title="Ingredients" class="mw-redirect">ingredients</a> from an animal source.
<br style="clear:both;" />
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Production">Production</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Ueberladewagen_(jha).jpg" title="File:Ueberladewagen (jha).jpg">File:Ueberladewagen (jha).jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Tractor" title="Tractor">Tractor</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Chaser_bin&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chaser bin (page does not exist)">Chaser bin</a></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Most food has always been obtained through <a href="/wiki/Agriculture" title="Agriculture">agriculture</a>. With increasing concern over both the methods and products of modern <a href="/w/index.php?title=Industrial_agriculture&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Industrial agriculture (page does not exist)">industrial agriculture</a>, there has been a growing trend toward <a href="/wiki/Sustainable_agriculture" title="Sustainable agriculture">sustainable agricultural</a> practices. This approach, partly fueled by consumer demand, encourages <a href="/wiki/Biodiversity" title="Biodiversity">biodiversity</a>, local self-reliance and <a href="/wiki/Organic_farming" title="Organic farming">organic farming</a> methods.<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9">[9]</a></sup> Major influences on food production include international organizations (e.g. the <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">World Trade Organization</a> and <a href="/wiki/Common_Agricultural_Policy" title="Common Agricultural Policy">Common Agricultural Policy</a>), national government policy (or law), and war.<sup id="cite_ref-Messer_10-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Messer-10">[10]</a></sup>
</p><p>In popular culture, the mass production of food, specifically meats such as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Chicken_(food)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chicken (food) (page does not exist)">chicken</a> and <a href="/wiki/Beef" title="Beef">beef</a>, has come under fire from various <a href="/wiki/Documentary_film" title="Documentary film">documentaries</a>, most recently <a href="/w/index.php?title=Food,_Inc&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Food, Inc (page does not exist)">Food, Inc</a>, documenting the mass slaughter and poor treatment of animals, often for easier revenues from <a href="/wiki/Corporate_farming" title="Corporate farming">large corporations</a>. Along with a current trend towards <a href="/wiki/Environmentalism" title="Environmentalism">environmentalism</a>, people in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Western_culture&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Western culture (page does not exist)">Western culture</a> have had an increasing trend towards the use of <a href="/wiki/Herbalism" title="Herbalism">herbal supplements</a>, foods for a specific group of person (such as dieters, women, or athletes), <a href="/wiki/Functional_food" title="Functional food">functional foods</a> (fortified foods, such as <a href="/wiki/Omega-3" title="Omega-3" class="mw-redirect">omega-3</a> eggs), and a more ethnically diverse diet.<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">[11]</a></sup>
</p><p>Several organisations have begun calling for a new kind of agriculture in which <a href="/wiki/Agroecosystem" title="Agroecosystem">agroecosystems</a> provide food but also support vital <a href="/wiki/Ecosystem" title="Ecosystem">ecosystem</a> services so that <a href="/wiki/Fertility_(soil)" title="Fertility (soil)">soil fertility</a> and <a href="/wiki/Biodiversity" title="Biodiversity">biodiversity</a> are maintained rather than compromised. According to the <a href="/wiki/International_Water_Management_Institute" title="International Water Management Institute">International Water Management Institute</a> and <a href="/wiki/UNEP" title="UNEP" class="mw-redirect">UNEP</a>, well-managed agroecosystems not only provide food, fiber and animal products, they also provide services such as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Flood_mitigation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Flood mitigation (page does not exist)">flood mitigation</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Groundwater_recharge&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Groundwater recharge (page does not exist)">groundwater recharge</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Erosion_control&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Erosion control (page does not exist)">erosion control</a> and habitats for plants, birds fish and other animals.<sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12">[12]</a></sup> 
<br style="clear:both;" />
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Taste_perception">Taste perception</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Animals, specifically humans, have five different types of tastes: <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sweet&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sweet (page does not exist)">sweet</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sour" title="Sour" class="mw-redirect">sour</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Saltiness&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Saltiness (page does not exist)">salty</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bitter_(taste)" title="Bitter (taste)" class="mw-redirect">bitter</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Umami" title="Umami">umami</a>. As animals have <a href="/wiki/Evolution" title="Evolution">evolved</a>, the tastes that provide the most energy (<a href="/wiki/Sugar" title="Sugar">sugar</a> and <a href="/wiki/Fat" title="Fat">fats</a>) are the most pleasant to eat while others, such as <a href="/wiki/Bitter_(taste)" title="Bitter (taste)" class="mw-redirect">bitter</a>, are not enjoyable.<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">[13]</a></sup> Water, while important for survival, has no taste.<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14">[14]</a></sup> Fats, on the other hand, especially <a href="/wiki/Saturated_fat" title="Saturated fat">saturated fats</a>, are thicker and rich and are thus considered more enjoyable to eat.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sweet">Sweet</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Saccharose2.svg" title="File:Saccharose2.svg">File:Saccharose2.svg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Structure of sucrose</div></div></div>
<p>Generally regarded as the most pleasant taste, <a href="/wiki/Sweetness" title="Sweetness">sweetness</a> is almost always caused by a type of simple <a href="/wiki/Sugar" title="Sugar">sugar</a> such as <a href="/wiki/Glucose" title="Glucose">glucose</a> or <a href="/wiki/Fructose" title="Fructose">fructose</a>, or <a href="/wiki/Disaccharides" title="Disaccharides" class="mw-redirect">disaccharides</a> such as <a href="/wiki/Sucrose" title="Sucrose">sucrose</a>, a molecule combining glucose and fructose.<sup id="cite_ref-New_Oxford_American_Dictionary_15-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-New_Oxford_American_Dictionary-15">[15]</a></sup> Complex carbohydrates are long chains and thus do not have the sweet taste. Artificial sweeteners such as <a href="/wiki/Sucralose" title="Sucralose">sucralose</a> are used to mimic the sugar molecule, creating the sensation of sweet, without the calories. Other types of sugar include <a href="/w/index.php?title=Raw_sugar&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Raw sugar (page does not exist)">raw sugar</a>, which is known for its amber color, as it is unprocessed. As sugar is vital for energy and survival, the taste of sugar is pleasant.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Stevia" title="Stevia">stevia</a> plant contains a compound known as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Steviol&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Steviol (page does not exist)">steviol</a> which, when extracted, has 300 times the sweetness of sugar while having minimal impact on blood sugar.<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">[16]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sour">Sour</span></h3>
<p>Sourness is caused by the taste of <a href="/wiki/Acid" title="Acid">acids</a>, such as <a href="/wiki/Vinegar" title="Vinegar">vinegar</a> in alcoholic beverages. Sour foods include <a href="/wiki/Citrus" title="Citrus">citrus</a>, specifically <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lemon&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lemon (page does not exist)">lemons</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lime_(fruit)" title="Lime (fruit)">limes</a>, and to a lesser degree <a href="/w/index.php?title=Orange_(fruit)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Orange (fruit) (page does not exist)">oranges</a>. Sour is evolutionarily significant as it is a sign for a food that may have gone <a href="/wiki/Rancidity" title="Rancidity" class="mw-redirect">rancid</a> due to bacteria.<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">[17]</a></sup> Many foods, however, are slightly acidic, and help stimulate the taste buds and enhance flavor.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Salty">Salty</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Piles_of_Salt_Salar_de_Uyuni_Bolivia_Luca_Galuzzi_2006_a.jpg" title="File:Piles of Salt Salar de Uyuni Bolivia Luca Galuzzi 2006 a.jpg">File:Piles of Salt Salar de Uyuni Bolivia Luca Galuzzi 2006 a.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Salt mounds in <a href="/wiki/Bolivia" title="Bolivia">Bolivia</a>.</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Saltiness&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Saltiness (page does not exist)">Saltiness</a> is the taste of <a href="/wiki/Alkali_metal" title="Alkali metal">alkali metal</a> <a href="/wiki/Ions" title="Ions" class="mw-redirect">ions</a> such as <a href="/wiki/Sodium" title="Sodium">sodium</a> and <a href="/wiki/Potassium" title="Potassium">potassium</a>. It is found in almost every food in low to moderate proportions to enhance flavor, although to eat pure salt is regarded as highly unpleasant. There are many different types of salt, with each having a different degree of saltiness, including <a href="/wiki/Sea_salt" title="Sea salt">sea salt</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fleur_de_sel&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fleur de sel (page does not exist)">fleur de sel</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kosher_salt" title="Kosher salt">kosher salt</a>, mined salt, and grey salt. Other than enhancing flavor, its significance is that the body needs and maintains a delicate <a href="/wiki/Electrolyte" title="Electrolyte">electrolyte</a> balance, which is the <a href="/wiki/Kidney" title="Kidney">kidney</a>'s function. Salt may be iodized, meaning <a href="/wiki/Iodine" title="Iodine">iodine</a> has been added to it, a necessary nutrient that promotes <a href="/wiki/Thyroid" title="Thyroid">thyroid</a> function. Some canned foods, notably <a href="/w/index.php?title=Soup&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Soup (page does not exist)">soups</a> or packaged <a href="/wiki/Broth" title="Broth">broths</a>, tend to be high in salt as a means of preserving the food longer. Historically speaking, salt has been used as a meat preservative as salt promotes water excretion, thus working as a preservative. Similarly, dried foods also promote food safety.<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">[18]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Bitter">Bitter</span></h3>
<p><a href="/wiki/Bitter_(taste)" title="Bitter (taste)" class="mw-redirect">Bitterness</a> is a sensation often considered unpleasant characterized by having a sharp, pungent taste. Dark, unsweetened <a href="/wiki/Chocolate" title="Chocolate">chocolate</a>, <a href="/wiki/Caffeine" title="Caffeine">caffeine</a>, lemon rind, and some types of fruit are known to be bitter.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Umami">Umami</span></h3>
<p><a href="/wiki/Umami" title="Umami">Umami</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Japanese_language" title="Japanese language">Japanese</a> word for delicious, is the least known in Western popular culture but has a long tradition in Asian cuisine. Umami is the taste of <a href="/wiki/Glutamate" title="Glutamate" class="mw-redirect">glutamates</a>, especially <a href="/wiki/Monosodium_glutamate" title="Monosodium glutamate">monosodium glutamate</a> (MSG).<sup id="cite_ref-New_Oxford_American_Dictionary_15-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-New_Oxford_American_Dictionary-15">[15]</a></sup> It is characterized as savory, meaty, and rich in flavor. <a href="/wiki/Salmon" title="Salmon">Salmon</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mushrooms" title="Mushrooms" class="mw-redirect">mushrooms</a> are foods high in umami. Meat and other animal byproducts are described as having this taste.{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}}
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Cuisine">Cuisine</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Many cultures have a recognizable cuisine, a specific set of <a href="/wiki/Cooking" title="Cooking">cooking</a> traditions using various spices or a combination of flavors unique to that culture, which evolves over time. Other differences include preferences (hot or cold, spicy, etc.) and practices, the study of which is known as <a href="/wiki/Gastronomy" title="Gastronomy">gastronomy</a>. Many cultures have diversified their foods by means of preparation, cooking methods, and manufacturing. This also includes a complex food trade which helps the cultures to economically survive by way of food, not just by consumption. Some popular types of ethnic foods include <a href="/w/index.php?title=Italian_cuisine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Italian cuisine (page does not exist)">Italian</a>, <a href="/wiki/French_cuisine" title="French cuisine">French</a>, <a href="/wiki/Japanese_cuisine" title="Japanese cuisine">Japanese</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chinese_cuisine" title="Chinese cuisine">Chinese</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cuisine_of_the_United_States" title="Cuisine of the United States">American</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cajun_cuisine" title="Cajun cuisine">Cajun</a>, <a href="/wiki/Thai_cuisine" title="Thai cuisine">Thai</a>, African, and <a href="/wiki/Indian_cuisine" title="Indian cuisine">Indian</a> cuisine. Various cultures throughout the world study the dietary analysis of food <a href="/w/index.php?title=Habit_(psychology)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Habit (psychology) (page does not exist)">habits</a>. While <a href="/wiki/Evolution" title="Evolution">evolutionarily</a> speaking, as opposed to culturally, humans are <a href="/w/index.php?title=Omnivore&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Omnivore (page does not exist)">omnivores</a>, religion and social constructs such as <a href="/wiki/Morality" title="Morality">morality</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Activism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Activism (page does not exist)">activism</a>, or <a href="/wiki/Environmentalism" title="Environmentalism">environmentalism</a> will often affect which foods they will consume. Food is eaten and typically enjoyed through the sense of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Taste&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Taste (page does not exist)">taste</a>, the perception of flavor from eating and drinking. Certain tastes are more enjoyable than others, for evolutionary purposes.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Presentation">Presentation</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Terrine_de_saumon_au_basilic.JPG" title="File:Terrine de saumon au basilic.JPG">File:Terrine de saumon au basilic.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">A <a href="/w/index.php?title=France&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="France (page does not exist)">French</a> basil salmon <a href="/w/index.php?title=Terrine_(food)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Terrine (food) (page does not exist)">terrine</a>, with eye-appealing <a href="/wiki/Garnish_(food)" title="Garnish (food)">garnishes</a></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Aesthetically pleasing and eye-appealing food presentations can encourage people to consume foods. A common saying is that people "eat with their eyes". Food presented in a clean and appetizing way will encourage a good flavor, even if unsatisfactory.<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">[19]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Food_Texture.2C_Andrew_J._Rosenthal_20-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Food_Texture.2C_Andrew_J._Rosenthal-20">[20]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Contrast_in_texture">Contrast in texture</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Texture_(food)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Texture (food) (page does not exist)">Texture</a> plays a crucial role in the enjoyment of eating foods. Contrasts in textures, such as something crunchy in an otherwise smooth dish, may increase the appeal of eating it. Common examples include adding <a href="/wiki/Granola" title="Granola">granola</a> to <a href="/wiki/Yogurt" title="Yogurt">yogurt</a>, adding <a href="/wiki/Crouton" title="Crouton">croutons</a> to a <a href="/wiki/Salad" title="Salad">salad</a> or <a href="/w/index.php?title=Soup&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Soup (page does not exist)">soup</a>, and toasting bread to enhance its crunchiness for a smooth topping, such as jam or butter.<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21">[21]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Contrast_in_taste">Contrast in taste</span></h3>
<p>Another universal phenomenon regarding food is the appeal of contrast in taste and presentation. For example, such opposite flavors as <a href="/wiki/Sweetness" title="Sweetness">sweetness</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Saltiness&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Saltiness (page does not exist)">saltiness</a> tend to go well together, as in <a href="/wiki/Kettle_corn" title="Kettle corn">kettle corn</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nut_(fruit)" title="Nut (fruit)">nuts</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Food_preparation">Food preparation</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
While many foods can be eaten raw, many also undergo some form of preparation for reasons of safety, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Palatability&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Palatability (page does not exist)">palatability</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mouthfeel&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mouthfeel (page does not exist)">texture</a>, or <a href="/wiki/Flavor" title="Flavor">flavor</a>. At the simplest level this may involve washing, cutting, trimming, or adding other foods or ingredients, such as spices. It may also involve mixing, heating or cooling, <a href="/wiki/Pressure_cooking" title="Pressure cooking">pressure cooking</a>, fermentation, or combination with other food. In a home, most food preparation takes place in a <a href="/wiki/Kitchen" title="Kitchen">kitchen</a>. Some preparation is done to enhance the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Taste&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Taste (page does not exist)">taste</a> or aesthetic appeal; other preparation may help to <a href="/wiki/Food_preservation" title="Food preservation">preserve</a> the food; others may be involved in cultural identity. A <a href="/wiki/Meal" title="Meal">meal</a> is made up of food which is prepared to be eaten at a specific time and place.<sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22">[22]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:LG_refrigerator_interior.jpg" title="File:LG refrigerator interior.jpg">File:LG refrigerator interior.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">A refrigerator helps to keep foods fresh.</div></div></div>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Animal_preparation">Animal preparation</span></h4>
<p>The preparation of animal-based food usually involves <a href="/w/index.php?title=Slaughter_(livestock)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Slaughter (livestock) (page does not exist)">slaughter</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Evisceration_(organ_removal)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Evisceration (organ removal) (page does not exist)">evisceration</a>, hanging, portioning, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rendering_(food_processing)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rendering (food processing) (page does not exist)">rendering</a>. In developed countries, this is usually done outside the home in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Slaughterhouses&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Slaughterhouses (page does not exist)">slaughterhouses</a>, which are used to process animals en masse for meat production. Many countries regulate their slaughterhouses by law. For example, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_States&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United States (page does not exist)">United States</a> has established the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Humane_Slaughter_Act&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Humane Slaughter Act (page does not exist)">Humane Slaughter Act</a> of 1958, which requires that an animal be stunned before killing. This act, like those in many countries, exempts slaughter in accordance to religious law, such as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kosher&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kosher (page does not exist)">kosher</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shechita" title="Shechita">shechita</a>, and dhabiĥa halal. Strict interpretations of <a href="/wiki/Kashrut" title="Kashrut">kashrut</a> require the animal to be fully aware when its carotid artery is cut.<sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23">[23]</a></sup>
</p><p>On the local level, a butcher may commonly break down larger animal meat into smaller manageable cuts, and pre-wrap them for commercial sale or wrap them to order in butcher paper. In addition, fish and <a href="/wiki/Seafood" title="Seafood">seafood</a> may be fabricated into smaller cuts by a fish monger. However fish butchery may be done on board a fishing vessel and quick-frozen for preservation of quality.<sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24">[24]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Cooking">Cooking</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Wok_cooking_and_the_heat_source_by_The_Pocket_in_Nanjing.jpg" title="File:Wok cooking and the heat source by The Pocket in Nanjing.jpg">File:Wok cooking and the heat source by The Pocket in Nanjing.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Cooking with a <a href="/wiki/Wok" title="Wok">wok</a> in <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>The term "cooking" encompasses a vast range of methods, tools, and combinations of ingredients to improve the flavor or digestibility of food. Cooking technique, known as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Culinary_art&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Culinary art (page does not exist)">culinary art</a>, generally requires the selection, measurement, and combining of ingredients in an ordered procedure in an effort to achieve the desired result. Constraints on success include the variability of ingredients, ambient conditions, <a href="/wiki/Tool" title="Tool">tools</a>, and the skill of the individual cook.<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25">[25]</a></sup> The diversity of cooking worldwide is a reflection of the myriad nutritional, aesthetic, agricultural, economic, cultural, and religious considerations that affect it.<sup id="cite_ref-silhnc_26-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-silhnc-26">[26]</a></sup>
</p><p>Cooking requires applying heat to a food which usually, though not always, chemically changes the molecules, thus changing its flavor, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mouthfeel&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mouthfeel (page does not exist)">texture</a>, appearance, and nutritional properties.<sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">[27]</a></sup> Cooking certain proteins, such as egg whites, meats, and fish, denatures the protein, causing it to firm. There is archaeological evidence of roasted foodstuffs at <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Homo_erectus&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Homo erectus (page does not exist)">Homo erectus</a></i> campsites dating from 420,000 years ago.<sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">[28]</a></sup> Boiling as a means of cooking requires a container, and has been practiced at least since the 10th millennium BC with the introduction of <a href="/wiki/Pottery" title="Pottery">pottery</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">[29]</a></sup>
</p>
<h5><span class="mw-headline" id="Cooking_equipment">Cooking equipment</span></h5>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Pfanne_(Edelstahl).jpg" title="File:Pfanne (Edelstahl).jpg">File:Pfanne (Edelstahl).jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">A <a href="/wiki/Stainless_steel" title="Stainless steel">stainless steel</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Frying_pan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Frying pan (page does not exist)">frying pan</a></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:TraditionalAsado.jpg" title="File:TraditionalAsado.jpg">File:TraditionalAsado.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">A traditional <a href="/wiki/Asado" title="Asado">asado</a> (barbecue)</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>There are many different types of equipment used for cooking.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Oven" title="Oven">Ovens</a> are mostly hollow devices that get very hot (up to 500 °F) and are used for baking or roasting and offer a dry-heat cooking method. Different cuisines will use different types of ovens; for example, Indian culture uses a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tandoor&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tandoor (page does not exist)">Tandoor</a> oven, which is a cylindrical clay oven which operates at a single high temperature.<sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30">[30]</a></sup> Western kitchens use variable temperature <a href="/wiki/Convection_oven" title="Convection oven">convection ovens</a>, conventional ovens, <a href="/wiki/Toaster_oven" title="Toaster oven" class="mw-redirect">toaster ovens</a>, or non-radiant heat ovens like the <a href="/wiki/Microwave_oven" title="Microwave oven">microwave oven</a>. Classic Italian cuisine includes the use of a brick oven containing burning wood. Ovens may be wood-fired, coal-fired, <a href="/wiki/Natural_gas" title="Natural gas">gas</a>, electric, or oil-fired.<sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31">[31]</a></sup>
</p><p>Various types of cook-tops are used as well. They carry the same variations of fuel types as the ovens mentioned above. Cook-tops are used to heat vessels placed on top of the heat source, such as a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Saut%C3%A9_pan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sauté pan (page does not exist)">sauté pan</a>, sauce pot, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Frying_pan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Frying pan (page does not exist)">frying pan</a>, or <a href="/wiki/Pressure_cooker" title="Pressure cooker" class="mw-redirect">pressure cooker</a>. These pieces of equipment can use either a moist or dry cooking method and include methods such as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Steam&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Steam (page does not exist)">steaming</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Simmer&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Simmer (page does not exist)">simmering</a>, <a href="/wiki/Boil" title="Boil">boiling</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Poaching_(cooking)" title="Poaching (cooking)">poaching</a> for moist methods, while the dry methods include <a href="/wiki/Saut%C3%A9" title="Sauté" class="mw-redirect">sautéing</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pan_fry&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pan fry (page does not exist)">pan frying</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Deep-fry&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Deep-fry (page does not exist)">deep-frying</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32">[32]</a></sup>
</p><p>In addition, many cultures use grills for cooking. A <a href="/w/index.php?title=Grill_(cooking)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Grill (cooking) (page does not exist)">grill</a> operates with a radiant heat source from below, usually covered with a metal grid and sometimes a cover. An open pit barbecue in the American south is one example along with the American style outdoor grill fueled by wood, liquid propane, or charcoal along with soaked wood chips for smoking.<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33">[33]</a></sup> A <a href="/wiki/Mexican_cuisine" title="Mexican cuisine">Mexican</a> style of barbecue is called <a href="/wiki/Barbacoa" title="Barbacoa">barbacoa</a>, which involves the cooking of meats such as whole sheep over an open fire. In <a href="/w/index.php?title=Argentina&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Argentina (page does not exist)">Argentina</a>, an <a href="/wiki/Asado" title="Asado">asado</a> (Spanish for "grilled") is prepared on a grill held over an open pit or fire made upon the ground, on which a whole animal or smaller cuts are grilled.<sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34">[34]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Raw_food_preparation.7B.7B.23invoke:anchor.7Cmain.7D.7D">Raw food preparation{{#invoke:anchor|main}}</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:2007feb-sushi-odaiba-manytypes.jpg" title="File:2007feb-sushi-odaiba-manytypes.jpg">File:2007feb-sushi-odaiba-manytypes.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Many types of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fish&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fish (page does not exist)">fish</a> ready to be eaten, including <a href="/wiki/Salmon" title="Salmon">salmon</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tuna" title="Tuna">tuna</a>.</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>Certain cultures highlight animal and vegetable foods in their raw state. <a href="/wiki/Salad" title="Salad">Salads</a> consisting of raw vegetables or fruits are common in many cuisines. <a href="/wiki/Sashimi" title="Sashimi">Sashimi</a> in <a href="/wiki/Japanese_cuisine" title="Japanese cuisine">Japanese cuisine</a> consists of raw sliced <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fish&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fish (page does not exist)">fish</a> or other meat, and <a href="/wiki/Sushi" title="Sushi">sushi</a> often incorporates raw fish or seafood. <a href="/wiki/Steak_tartare" title="Steak tartare">Steak tartare</a> and salmon tartare are dishes made from diced or ground raw beef or salmon, mixed with various ingredients and served with <a href="/wiki/Baguette" title="Baguette">baguettes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Brioche" title="Brioche">brioche</a>, or <a href="/w/index.php?title=Frites&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Frites (page does not exist)">frites</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35">[35]</a></sup> In Italy, <a href="/wiki/Carpaccio" title="Carpaccio">carpaccio</a> is a dish of very thinly sliced raw <a href="/wiki/Beef" title="Beef">beef</a>, drizzled with a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Vinaigrette&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Vinaigrette (page does not exist)">vinaigrette</a> made with olive oil.<sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36">[36]</a></sup> The health food movement known as <a href="/wiki/Raw_foodism" title="Raw foodism">raw foodism</a> promotes a mostly <a href="/w/index.php?title=Vegan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Vegan (page does not exist)">vegan</a> diet of raw fruits, vegetables, and grains prepared in various ways, including juicing, food dehydration, sprouting, and other methods of preparation that do not heat the food above <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37">[37]</a></sup> An example of a raw meat dish is <a href="/wiki/Ceviche" title="Ceviche">ceviche</a>, a Latin American dish made with raw meat that is "cooked" from the highly acidic citric juice from lemons and limes along with other aromatics such as garlic.
<br style="clear:both;" />
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Restaurants">Restaurants</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Allyn_House_restaurant_menu_(March_5,_1859).jpg" title="File:Allyn House restaurant menu (March 5, 1859).jpg">File:Allyn House restaurant menu (March 5, 1859).jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Allyn House restaurant menu (March 5, 1859)</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Mcdonalds_Restaurant_Riyadh.JPG" title="File:Mcdonalds Restaurant Riyadh.JPG">File:Mcdonalds Restaurant Riyadh.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/w/index.php?title=McDonald%27s&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="McDonald's (page does not exist)">McDonald's</a> restaurant, <a href="/wiki/Riyadh,_Saudi_Arabia" title="Riyadh, Saudi Arabia" class="mw-redirect">Riyadh, Saudi Arabia</a></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Restaurant.jpg" title="File:Restaurant.jpg">File:Restaurant.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tom%27s_Restaurant_(Manhattan)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tom's Restaurant (Manhattan) (page does not exist)">Tom's Restaurant</a>, a restaurant in <a href="/wiki/New_York_City" title="New York City">New York City</a></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Restaurants employ trained <a href="/wiki/Chef" title="Chef">chefs</a> who prepare food, and trained waitstaff to serve the customers. The term <a href="/wiki/Restaurant" title="Restaurant">restaurant</a> is credited to the <a href="/w/index.php?title=France&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="France (page does not exist)">French</a> from the 19th century, as it relates to the restorative nature of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bouillon_(broth)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bouillon (broth) (page does not exist)">bouillons</a> that were once served in them. However, the concept pre-dates the naming of these establishments, as evidence suggests commercial food preparation may have existed during the age of the city of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pompeii&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pompeii (page does not exist)">Pompeii</a>, and urban sales of prepared foods may have existed in <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a> during the <a href="/wiki/Song_Dynasty" title="Song Dynasty">Song Dynasty</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Coffeehouse" title="Coffeehouse">coffee shops</a> or <a href="/wiki/Caf%C3%A9" title="Café" class="mw-redirect">cafés</a> of 17th century <a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe">Europe</a> may also be considered an early version of the restaurant.<sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38">[38]</a></sup> In 2005, the population of the United States spent $496 billion for out-of-home <a href="/wiki/Dining" title="Dining" class="mw-redirect">dining</a>. Expenditures by type of out-of-home dining were as follows: 40% in full-service restaurants, 37.2% in limited service restaurants (<a href="/wiki/Fast_food" title="Fast food">fast food</a>), 6.6% in schools or colleges, 5.4% in bars and <a href="/wiki/Vending_machine" title="Vending machine">vending machines</a>, 4.7% in hotels and motels, 4.0% in recreational places, and 2.2% in others, which includes military bases.<sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39">[39]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Food_manufacturing">Food manufacturing</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Packages.jpg" title="File:Packages.jpg">File:Packages.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Packaged household food items</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Packaged foods are manufactured outside the home for purchase. This can be as simple as a <a href="/wiki/Butcher" title="Butcher">butcher</a> preparing meat, or as complex as a modern international <a href="/w/index.php?title=Food_industry&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Food industry (page does not exist)">food industry</a>. Early food processing techniques were limited by available food preservation, packaging, and transportation. This mainly involved <a href="/wiki/Salting_(food)" title="Salting (food)">salting</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Curing_(food_preservation)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Curing (food preservation) (page does not exist)">curing</a>, curdling, <a href="/wiki/Drying_(food)" title="Drying (food)">drying</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pickling" title="Pickling">pickling</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fermentation_(food)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fermentation (food) (page does not exist)">fermenting</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Smoking_(food)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Smoking (food) (page does not exist)">smoking</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40">[40]</a></sup> Food manufacturing arose during the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Industrial_revolution&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Industrial revolution (page does not exist)">industrial revolution</a> in the 19th century.<sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41">[41]</a></sup> This development took advantage of new <a href="/wiki/Mass-marketing" title="Mass-marketing" class="mw-redirect">mass markets</a> and emerging new technology, such as <a href="/wiki/Mill_(grinding)" title="Mill (grinding)">milling</a>, preservation, <a href="/wiki/Packaging" title="Packaging" class="mw-redirect">packaging</a> and <a href="/wiki/Packaging_and_labeling" title="Packaging and labeling">labeling</a>, and transportation. It brought the advantages of pre-prepared time-saving food to the bulk of ordinary people who did not employ domestic servants.<sup id="cite_ref-Jango_42-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Jango-42">[42]</a></sup>
</p><p>At the start of the 21st century, a two-tier structure has arisen, with a few international food processing giants controlling a wide range of well-known food <a href="/w/index.php?title=Brand&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Brand (page does not exist)">brands</a>. There also exists a wide array of small local or national food processing companies.<sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43">[43]</a></sup> Advanced technologies have also come to change food manufacture. Computer-based control systems, sophisticated <a href="/wiki/Food_processing" title="Food processing">processing</a> and packaging methods, and <a href="/wiki/Logistics" title="Logistics">logistics</a> and <a href="/wiki/Food_distribution" title="Food distribution">distribution</a> advances can enhance product quality, improve <a href="/w/index.php?title=Food_safety&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Food safety (page does not exist)">food safety</a>, and reduce costs.<sup id="cite_ref-Jango_42-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Jango-42">[42]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Commercial_trade">Commercial trade</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:2005food_import.png" title="File:2005food import.png">File:2005food import.png</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Food <a href="/w/index.php?title=Import&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Import (page does not exist)">imports</a> in 2005</div></div></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="International_exports_and_imports">International exports and imports</span></h3>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">World Bank</a> reported that the European Union was the top food importer in 2005, followed at a distance by the USA and Japan. Food is now traded and marketed on a global basis. The variety and availability of food is no longer restricted by the diversity of locally grown food or the limitations of the local growing season.<sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44">[44]</a></sup> Between 1961 and 1999, there was a 400% increase in worldwide food exports.<sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45">[45]</a></sup> Some countries are now economically dependent on food exports, which in some cases account for over 80% of all exports.<sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46">[46]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1994, over 100 countries became signatories to the <a href="/wiki/Uruguay_Round" title="Uruguay Round">Uruguay Round</a> of the <a href="/wiki/General_Agreement_on_Tariffs_and_Trade" title="General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade">General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade</a> in a dramatic increase in <a href="/wiki/Trade_liberalization" title="Trade liberalization" class="mw-redirect">trade liberalization</a>. This included an agreement to reduce subsidies paid to farmers, underpinned by the <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">WTO</a> enforcement of <a href="/wiki/Agricultural_policy" title="Agricultural policy">agricultural subsidy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tax,_tariff_and_trade" title="Tax, tariff and trade" class="mw-redirect">tariffs</a>, import <a href="/w/index.php?title=Quota_Share&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Quota Share (page does not exist)">quotas</a>, and settlement of trade disputes that cannot be bilaterally resolved.<sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47">[47]</a></sup> Where trade barriers are raised on the disputed grounds of public health and safety, the WTO refer the dispute to the <a href="/wiki/Codex_Alimentarius" title="Codex Alimentarius">Codex Alimentarius</a> Commission, which was founded in 1962 by the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a> <a href="/wiki/Food_and_Agriculture_Organization" title="Food and Agriculture Organization">Food and Agriculture Organization</a> and the World Health Organization. Trade liberalization has greatly affected world food trade.<sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48">[48]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Marketing_and_retailing">Marketing and retailing</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Fredmeyer_edit_1.jpg" title="File:Fredmeyer edit 1.jpg">File:Fredmeyer edit 1.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Packaged food aisles of supermarket in <a href="/wiki/Portland,_Oregon" title="Portland, Oregon">Portland, Oregon</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_States&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United States (page does not exist)">United States of America</a></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Food_marketing&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Food marketing (page does not exist)">Food marketing</a> brings together the producer and the consumer. It is the chain of activities that brings food from "farm gate to plate".<sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49">[49]</a></sup> The marketing of even a single food product can be a complicated process involving many producers and companies. For example, fifty-six companies are involved in making one <a href="/wiki/Canning" title="Canning">can</a> of chicken noodle soup. These businesses include not only chicken and vegetable processors but also the companies that transport the ingredients and those who print labels and manufacture cans.<sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50">[50]</a></sup> The food marketing system is the largest direct and indirect non-government employer in the United States.
</p><p>In the pre-modern era, the sale of surplus food took place once a week when farmers took their wares on market day into the local village marketplace. Here food was sold to <a href="/wiki/Grocer" title="Grocer">grocers</a> for sale in their local shops for purchase by local consumers.<sup id="cite_ref-silhnc_26-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-silhnc-26">[26]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Jango_42-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Jango-42">[42]</a></sup> With the onset of industrialization and the development of the food processing industry, a wider range of food could be sold and distributed in distant locations. Typically early grocery shops would be <a href="/wiki/Counter" title="Counter">counter</a>-based shops, in which purchasers told the shop-keeper what they wanted, so that the shop-keeper could get it for them.<sup id="cite_ref-silhnc_26-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-silhnc-26">[26]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51">[51]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the 20th century, <a href="/wiki/Supermarket" title="Supermarket">supermarkets</a> were born. Supermarkets brought with them a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Self_service&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Self service (page does not exist)">self service</a> approach to shopping using <a href="/wiki/Shopping_cart" title="Shopping cart">shopping carts</a>, and were able to offer quality food at lower cost through <a href="/wiki/Economies_of_scale" title="Economies of scale">economies of scale</a> and reduced staffing costs. In the latter part of the 20th century, this has been further revolutionized by the development of vast warehouse-sized, out-of-town supermarkets, selling a wide range of food from around the world.<sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52">[52]</a></sup>
</p><p>Unlike food processors, food retailing is a two-tier market in which a small number of very large <a href="/wiki/Corporation" title="Corporation">companies</a> control a large proportion of supermarkets. The supermarket giants wield great purchasing power over farmers and processors, and strong influence over consumers. Nevertheless, less than 10% of consumer spending on food goes to farmers, with larger percentages going to <a href="/wiki/Advertising" title="Advertising">advertising</a>, transportation, and intermediate corporations.<sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53">[53]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Prices">Prices</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:GrainProducts.jpg" title="File:GrainProducts.jpg">File:GrainProducts.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Some essential food products including <a href="/wiki/Bread" title="Bread">bread</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rice" title="Rice">rice</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pasta" title="Pasta">pasta</a></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
It was reported on March 24, 2008, that consumers worldwide faced rising food prices.<sup id="cite_ref-cnn24march2008_54-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cnn24march2008-54">[54]</a></sup> Reasons for this development include changes in the weather and dramatic changes in the <a href="/wiki/Global_economy" title="Global economy" class="mw-redirect">global economy</a>, including higher <a href="/w/index.php?title=Oil_price&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Oil price (page does not exist)">oil prices</a>, lower food reserves, and growing consumer demand in <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a> and <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-cnn24march2008_54-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cnn24march2008-54">[54]</a></sup> In the long term, prices are expected to stabilize.<sup id="cite_ref-cnn24march2008_54-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cnn24march2008-54">[54]</a></sup> Farmers will grow more grain for both <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fuel&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fuel (page does not exist)">fuel</a> and food and eventually bring prices down.<sup id="cite_ref-cnn24march2008_54-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cnn24march2008-54">[54]</a></sup> Already this is happening with <a href="/wiki/Wheat" title="Wheat">wheat</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55">[55]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56">[56]</a></sup> with more <a href="/wiki/Crops" title="Crops" class="mw-redirect">crops</a> to be planted in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_States&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United States (page does not exist)">United States</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Canada&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Canada (page does not exist)">Canada</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe">Europe</a> in 2009. However, the <a href="/wiki/Food_and_Agriculture_Organization" title="Food and Agriculture Organization">Food and Agriculture Organization</a> projects that consumers still have to deal with more expensive food until at least 2018.<sup id="cite_ref-cnn24march2008_54-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cnn24march2008-54">[54]</a></sup>
</p><p>It is rare for the spikes to hit all major foods in most countries at once. Food prices rose 4% in the United States in 2007, the highest increase since 1990, and are expected to climb as much again in 2008. As of December 2007, 37 countries faced food crises, and 20 had imposed some sort of food-price controls. In China, the price of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pork&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pork (page does not exist)">pork</a> jumped 58% in 2007. In the 1980s and 1990s, farm subsidies and support programs allowed major grain exporting countries to hold large surpluses, which could be tapped during food shortages to keep prices down. However, new trade policies have made agricultural production much more responsive to market demands, putting global food reserves at their lowest since 1983.<sup id="cite_ref-cnn24march2008_54-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cnn24march2008-54">[54]</a></sup>
</p><p>Food prices are rising, wealthier Asian consumers are westernizing their diets, and farmers and nations of the third world are struggling to keep up the pace. The past five years have seen rapid growth in the contribution of Asian nations to the global fluid and powdered milk manufacturing industry, which in 2008 accounted for more than 30% of production, while China alone accounts for more than 10% of both production and consumption in the global fruit and vegetable processing and preserving industry. The trend is similarly evident in industries such as soft drink and bottled water manufacturing, as well as global cocoa, chocolate, and sugar confectionery manufacturing, forecast to grow by 5.7% and 10.0% respectively during 2008 in response to soaring demand in Chinese and Southeast Asian markets.<sup id="cite_ref-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-57">[57]</a></sup>
</p><p>Rising food prices over recent years have been linked with social unrest around the world, including rioting in <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh" title="Bangladesh">Bangladesh</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mexico&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mexico (page does not exist)">Mexico</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Ind_58-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ind-58">[58]</a></sup> and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Arab_Spring&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Arab Spring (page does not exist)">Arab Spring</a>.{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}}
</p><p>In 2013 <a href="/wiki/Overseas_Development_Institute" title="Overseas Development Institute">Overseas Development Institute</a> researchers showed that <a href="/wiki/Rice" title="Rice">rice</a> has more than doubled in price since 2000, rising by 120% in real terms. This was as a result of shifts in trade policy and restocking by major producers. More fundamental drivers of increased prices are the higher costs of fertiliser, diesel and labour. Parts of Asia see rural wages rise with potential large benefits for the 1.3 billion (2008 estimate) of Asia's poor in reducing the poverty they face. However, this negatively impacts more vulnerable groups who don't share in the economic boom, especially in Asian and African coastal cities. The researchers said the threat means social-protection policies are needed to guard against price shocks. The research proposed that in the longer run, the rises present opportunities to export for Western African farmers with high potential for rice production to replace imports with domestic production.<sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59">[59]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="As_investment">As investment</span></h3>
<p>Institutions such as <a href="/wiki/Hedge_fund" title="Hedge fund">hedge funds</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pension_fund" title="Pension fund">pension funds</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Investment_bank&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Investment bank (page does not exist)">investment banks</a> like <a href="/w/index.php?title=Barclays_Capital&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Barclays Capital (page does not exist)">Barclays Capital</a>, <a href="/wiki/Goldman_Sachs" title="Goldman Sachs">Goldman Sachs</a> and  <a href="/wiki/Morgan_Stanley" title="Morgan Stanley">Morgan Stanley</a><sup id="cite_ref-Ind_58-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ind-58">[58]</a></sup> have been instrumental in pushing up prices in the last five years, with investment in food <a href="/wiki/Commodity" title="Commodity">commodities</a> rising from $65bn to $126bn (£41bn to £79bn) between 2007 and 2012, contributing to 30-year highs. This has caused price fluctuations which are not strongly related to the actual supply of food, according to the United Nations.<sup id="cite_ref-Ind_58-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ind-58">[58]</a></sup> Financial institutions now make up 61% of all investment in <a href="/wiki/Wheat" title="Wheat">wheat</a> futures. According to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Olivier_De_Schutter&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Olivier De Schutter (page does not exist)">Olivier De Schutter</a>, the UN special rapporteur on food, there was a rush by institutions to enter the food market following <a href="/wiki/George_W_Bush" title="George W Bush" class="mw-redirect">George W Bush</a>'s <a href="/w/index.php?title=Commodities_Futures_Modernization_Act&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Commodities Futures Modernization Act (page does not exist)">Commodities Futures Modernization Act</a> of 2000.<sup id="cite_ref-Ind_58-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ind-58">[58]</a></sup> De Schutter told the Independent in March 2012: "What we are seeing now is that these financial markets have developed massively with the arrival of these new financial investors, who are purely interested in the short-term monetary gain and are not really interested in the physical thing – they never actually buy the ton of wheat or <a href="/w/index.php?title=Maize&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Maize (page does not exist)">maize</a>; they only buy a promise to buy or to sell. The result of this financialisation of the commodities market is that the prices of the products respond increasingly to a purely speculative logic. This explains why in very short periods of time we see prices spiking or bubbles exploding, because prices are less and less determined by the real match between supply and demand."<sup id="cite_ref-Ind_58-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ind-58">[58]</a></sup> In 2011, 450 economists from around the world called on the <a href="/w/index.php?title=G20&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="G20 (page does not exist)">G20</a> to regulate the commodities market more.<sup id="cite_ref-Ind_58-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ind-58">[58]</a></sup>
</p><p>Some experts have said that speculation has merely aggravated other factors, such as <a href="/wiki/Climate_change" title="Climate change">climate change</a>, competition with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bio-fuels&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bio-fuels (page does not exist)">bio-fuels</a> and overall rising demand.<sup id="cite_ref-Ind_58-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ind-58">[58]</a></sup> However, some such as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jayati_Ghosh&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jayati Ghosh (page does not exist)">Jayati Ghosh</a>, professor of economics at <a href="/wiki/Jawaharlal_Nehru_University" title="Jawaharlal Nehru University">Jawaharlal Nehru University</a> in <a href="/wiki/New_Delhi" title="New Delhi">New Delhi</a>, have pointed out that prices have increased irrespective of supply and demand issues: Ghosh points to world wheat prices, which doubled in the period from June to December 2010, despite there being no fall in global supply.<sup id="cite_ref-Ind_58-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ind-58">[58]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Famine_and_hunger">Famine and hunger</span></h2>
<p>Food deprivation leads to malnutrition and ultimately <a href="/wiki/Starvation" title="Starvation">starvation</a>. This is often connected with <a href="/wiki/Famine" title="Famine">famine</a>, which involves the absence of food in entire communities. This can have a devastating and widespread effect on human health and mortality. <a href="/wiki/Rationing" title="Rationing">Rationing</a> is sometimes used to distribute food in times of shortage, most notably during times of war.<sup id="cite_ref-Messer_10-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Messer-10">[10]</a></sup>
</p><p>Starvation is a significant international problem. Approximately 815 million people are undernourished, and over 16,000 children die per day from hunger-related causes.<sup id="cite_ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60">[60]</a></sup> Food deprivation is regarded as a deficit need in <a href="/wiki/Maslow%27s_hierarchy_of_needs" title="Maslow's hierarchy of needs">Maslow's hierarchy of needs</a> and is measured using <a href="/w/index.php?title=Famine_scales&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Famine scales (page does not exist)">famine scales</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61">[61]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Food_aid">Food aid</span></h3>
