<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/wiki/Food_aid" title="Food aid" class="mw-redirect">Food aid</a> can benefit people suffering from a shortage of food. It can be used to improve peoples' lives in the short term, so that a society can increase its standard of living to the point that food aid is no longer required.<sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62">[62]</a></sup> Conversely, badly managed food aid can create problems by disrupting local markets, depressing crop prices, and discouraging food production. Sometimes a cycle of food aid dependence can develop.<sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63">[63]</a></sup> Its provision, or threatened withdrawal, is sometimes used as a political tool to influence the policies of the destination country, a strategy known as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Food_politics&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Food politics (page does not exist)">food politics</a>. Sometimes, food aid provisions will require certain types of food be purchased from certain sellers, and food aid can be misused to enhance the markets of donor countries.<sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64">[64]</a></sup> International efforts to distribute food to the neediest countries are often coordinated by the <a href="/wiki/World_Food_Programme" title="World Food Programme">World Food Programme</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65">[65]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Safety">Safety</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:SalmonellaNIAID.jpg" title="File:SalmonellaNIAID.jpg">File:SalmonellaNIAID.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Salmonella" title="Salmonella">Salmonella</a> bacteria is a common cause of foodborne illness, particularly in undercooked <a href="/wiki/Chicken" title="Chicken">chicken</a> and <a href="/wiki/Chicken_egg" title="Chicken egg" class="mw-redirect">chicken eggs</a></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:HACCP_Seven_Principles.png" title="File:HACCP Seven Principles.png">File:HACCP Seven Principles.png</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Hazard Analysis and Critical Control Points (<a href="/wiki/HACCP" title="HACCP" class="mw-redirect">HACCP</a>) Flowchart</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Foodborne_illness" title="Foodborne illness">Foodborne illness</a>, commonly called "food poisoning", is caused by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bacteria&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bacteria (page does not exist)">bacteria</a>, <a href="/wiki/Toxin" title="Toxin">toxins</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Virus&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Virus (page does not exist)">viruses</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Parasite&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Parasite (page does not exist)">parasites</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Prion" title="Prion">prions</a>. Roughly 7 million people die of food poisoning each year, with about 10 times as many suffering from a non-fatal version.<sup id="cite_ref-MedlinePlus_66-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MedlinePlus-66">[66]</a></sup> The two most common factors leading to cases of bacterial foodborne illness are cross-contamination of ready-to-eat food from other uncooked foods and improper temperature control. Less commonly, acute adverse reactions can also occur if chemical contamination of food occurs, for example from improper storage, or use of non-food grade soaps and disinfectants. Food can also be adulterated by a very wide range of articles (known as "foreign bodies") during farming, manufacture, cooking, packaging, distribution, or sale. These foreign bodies can include pests or their droppings, hairs, cigarette butts, wood chips, and all manner of other contaminants. It is possible for certain types of food to become contaminated if stored or presented in an unsafe container, such as a ceramic pot with lead-based glaze.<sup id="cite_ref-MedlinePlus_66-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MedlinePlus-66">[66]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Food_poisoning" title="Food poisoning" class="mw-redirect">Food poisoning</a> has been recognized as a disease since as early as Hippocrates.<sup id="cite_ref-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-67">[67]</a></sup> The sale of <a href="/wiki/Rancidity" title="Rancidity" class="mw-redirect">rancid</a>, contaminated, or adulterated food was commonplace until the introduction of <a href="/wiki/Hygiene" title="Hygiene">hygiene</a>, refrigeration, and vermin controls in the 19th century. Discovery of techniques for killing bacteria using heat, and other <a href="/wiki/Microbiological" title="Microbiological" class="mw-redirect">microbiological</a> studies by scientists such as <a href="/wiki/Louis_Pasteur" title="Louis Pasteur">Louis Pasteur</a>, contributed to the modern sanitation standards that are ubiquitous in developed nations today. This was further underpinned by the work of <a href="/wiki/Justus_von_Liebig" title="Justus von Liebig">Justus von Liebig</a>, which led to the development of modern <a href="/wiki/Food_storage" title="Food storage">food storage</a> and <a href="/wiki/Food_preservation" title="Food preservation">food preservation</a> methods.<sup id="cite_ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68">[68]</a></sup> In more recent years, a greater understanding of the causes of food-borne illnesses has led to the development of more systematic approaches such as the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hazard_Analysis_and_Critical_Control_Points&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hazard Analysis and Critical Control Points (page does not exist)">Hazard Analysis and Critical Control Points</a> (<a href="/wiki/HACCP" title="HACCP" class="mw-redirect">HACCP</a>), which can identify and eliminate many risks.<sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69">[69]</a></sup>
</p><p>Recommended measures for ensuring food safety include maintaining a clean preparation area with foods of different types kept separate, ensuring an adequate cooking temperature, and refrigerating foods promptly after cooking.<sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70">[70]</a></sup>
</p><p>Foods that spoil easily, such as <a href="/wiki/Meats" title="Meats" class="mw-redirect">meats</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dairy" title="Dairy">dairy</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Seafood" title="Seafood">seafood</a>, must be prepared a certain way to avoid contaminating the people for whom they are prepared. As such, the general rule of thumb is that cold foods (such as dairy products) should be kept cold and hot foods (such as soup) should be kept hot until storage. Cold meats, such as chicken, that are to be cooked should not be placed at room temperature for thawing, at the risk of dangerous bacterial growth, such as <i><a href="/wiki/Salmonella" title="Salmonella">Salmonella</a></i> or <i><a href="/wiki/Escherichia_coli" title="Escherichia coli">E. coli</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71">[71]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Allergies">Allergies</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Some people have <a href="/wiki/Allergies" title="Allergies" class="mw-redirect">allergies</a> or sensitivities to foods which are not problematic to most people. This occurs when a person's <a href="/wiki/Immune_system" title="Immune system">immune system</a> mistakes a certain food protein for a harmful foreign agent and attacks it. About 2% of adults and 8% of children have a food allergy.<sup id="cite_ref-allergy_72-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-allergy-72">[72]</a></sup> The amount of the food substance required to provoke a reaction in a particularly susceptible individual can be quite small. In some instances, traces of food in the air, too minute to be perceived through smell, have been known to provoke lethal reactions in extremely sensitive individuals. Common food allergens are <a href="/wiki/Gluten" title="Gluten">gluten</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Maize&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Maize (page does not exist)">corn</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shellfish" title="Shellfish">shellfish</a> (mollusks), <a href="/wiki/Peanut" title="Peanut">peanuts</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Soy" title="Soy" class="mw-redirect">soy</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-allergy_72-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-allergy-72">[72]</a></sup> Allergens frequently produce symptoms such as <a href="/wiki/Diarrhea" title="Diarrhea">diarrhea</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rash" title="Rash">rashes</a>, bloating, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Vomiting&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Vomiting (page does not exist)">vomiting</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Regurgitation_(digestion)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Regurgitation (digestion) (page does not exist)">regurgitation</a>. The digestive complaints usually develop within half an hour of ingesting the <a href="/wiki/Allergen" title="Allergen">allergen</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-allergy_72-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-allergy-72">[72]</a></sup>
</p><p>Rarely, food allergies can lead to a <a href="/wiki/Medical_emergency" title="Medical emergency">medical emergency</a>, such as <a href="/wiki/Anaphylactic_shock" title="Anaphylactic shock" class="mw-redirect">anaphylactic shock</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hypotension" title="Hypotension">hypotension</a> (low blood pressure), and loss of consciousness. An allergen associated with this type of reaction is peanut, although <a href="/w/index.php?title=Latex&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Latex (page does not exist)">latex</a> products can induce similar reactions.<sup id="cite_ref-allergy_72-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-allergy-72">[72]</a></sup> Initial treatment is with <a href="/wiki/Epinephrine" title="Epinephrine">epinephrine</a> (adrenaline), often carried by known patients in the form of an <a href="/w/index.php?title=Epi-pen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Epi-pen (page does not exist)">Epi-pen</a> or <a href="/w/index.php?title=Twinject&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Twinject (page does not exist)">Twinject</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73">[73]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-74" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-74">[74]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Other_health_issues">Other health issues</span></h3>
<p>Human diet was estimated to cause perhaps around 35% of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Diet_and_cancer&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Diet and cancer (page does not exist)">cancers</a> in a human epidemiological analysis by <a href="/wiki/Richard_Doll" title="Richard Doll">Richard Doll</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Richard_Peto&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Richard Peto (page does not exist)">Richard Peto</a> in 1981.<sup id="cite_ref-75" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-75">[75]</a></sup>  These cancer may be caused by <a href="/wiki/Carcinogen" title="Carcinogen">carcinogens</a> that are present in food naturally or as contaminants. Food contaminated with fungal growth may contain <a href="/wiki/Mycotoxin" title="Mycotoxin">mycotoxins</a> such as <a href="/wiki/Aflatoxins" title="Aflatoxins" class="mw-redirect">aflatoxins</a> which may be found in contaminated corn and peanuts.  Other carcinogens identified in food include <a href="/w/index.php?title=Heterocyclic_amine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Heterocyclic amine (page does not exist)">heterocyclic amines</a> generated in meat when cooked at high temperature, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Polyaromatic_hydrocarbon&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Polyaromatic hydrocarbon (page does not exist)">polyaromatic hydrocarbons</a> in charred meat and smoked fish, and <a href="/wiki/Nitrosamine" title="Nitrosamine">nitrosamines</a> generated from nitrites used as food preservatives in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cured_meat&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cured meat (page does not exist)">cured meat</a> such as <a href="/wiki/Bacon" title="Bacon">bacon</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-carcinogens_and_anticarcinogens_76-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-carcinogens_and_anticarcinogens-76">[76]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Anticarcinogen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Anticarcinogen (page does not exist)">Anticarcinogens</a> that may help prevent cancer can also be found in many food especially fruits and vegetable.  <a href="/wiki/Antioxidant" title="Antioxidant">Antioxidants</a> are important groups of compounds that may help remove potentially harmful chemicals. It is however often difficult to identify the specific components in diet that serve to increase or decrease cancer risk since many food, such as beef steak and broccoli, contain low concentrations of both carcinogens and anticarcinogens.<sup id="cite_ref-carcinogens_and_anticarcinogens_76-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-carcinogens_and_anticarcinogens-76">[76]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Diet">Diet</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:FAO_kcal_his.png" title="File:FAO kcal his.png">File:FAO kcal his.png</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Changes of Food Supply (by energy)<sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77">[77]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78">[78]</a></sup><br />Other area (Yr 2010)<sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79">[79]</a></sup> * Africa, sub-Sahara - 2170 kcal/capita/day * N.E. and N. Africa - 3120 kcal/capita/day * South Asia - 2450 kcal/capita/day * East Asia - 3040 kcal/capita/day * Latin America / Caribbean - 2950  kcal/capita/day * Developed countries - 3470 kcal/capita/day</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cultural_and_religious_diets">Cultural and religious diets</span></h3>
<p>Dietary habits are the habitual decisions a person or culture makes when choosing what foods to eat.<sup id="cite_ref-Wansink_80-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Wansink-80">[80]</a></sup> Many cultures hold some food preferences and some food <a href="/wiki/Taboo" title="Taboo">taboos</a>. Dietary choices can also define cultures and play a role in religion. For example, only <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kosher&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kosher (page does not exist)">kosher foods</a> are permitted by <a href="/wiki/Judaism" title="Judaism">Judaism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Halal" title="Halal">halal</a> foods by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Islam&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Islam (page does not exist)">Islam</a>, and in <a href="/wiki/Hinduism" title="Hinduism">Hinduism</a> <a href="/wiki/Beef" title="Beef">beef</a> is restricted.<sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81">[81]</a></sup> In addition, the dietary choices of different countries or regions have different characteristics. This is highly related to a culture's <a href="/wiki/Cuisine" title="Cuisine">cuisine</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Diet_deficiencies">Diet deficiencies</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Dietary habits play a significant role in the health and mortality of all humans. Imbalances between the consumed fuels and expended energy results in either starvation or excessive reserves of <a href="/wiki/Adipose" title="Adipose" class="mw-redirect">adipose</a> tissue, known as body fat.<sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82">[82]</a></sup> Poor intake of various vitamins and minerals can lead to diseases that can have far-reaching effects on health. For instance, 30% of the world's population either has, or is at risk for developing, <a href="/wiki/Iodine_deficiency" title="Iodine deficiency">iodine deficiency</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83">[83]</a></sup> It is estimated that at least 3 million children are blind due to <a href="/wiki/Vitamin_A" title="Vitamin A">vitamin A</a> deficiency.<sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84">[84]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Vitamin_C" title="Vitamin C">Vitamin C</a> deficiency results in <a href="/wiki/Scurvy" title="Scurvy">scurvy</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85">[85]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Calcium" title="Calcium">Calcium</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Vitamin_D&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Vitamin D (page does not exist)">Vitamin D</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Phosphorus" title="Phosphorus">phosphorus</a> are inter-related; the consumption of each may affect the absorption of the others. <a href="/wiki/Kwashiorkor" title="Kwashiorkor">Kwashiorkor</a> and <a href="/wiki/Marasmus" title="Marasmus">marasmus</a> are childhood disorders caused by lack of dietary protein.<sup id="cite_ref-86" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-86">[86]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Moral.2C_ethical.2C_and_health-conscious_diets">Moral, ethical, and health-conscious diets</span></h3>
<p>Many individuals limit what foods they eat for reasons of morality, or other habit. For instance, <a href="/wiki/Vegetarian" title="Vegetarian" class="mw-redirect">vegetarians</a> choose to forgo food from animal sources to varying degrees. Others choose a <a href="/wiki/Healthy_diet" title="Healthy diet">healthier diet</a>, avoiding sugars or animal fats and increasing consumption of dietary fiber and <a href="/wiki/Antioxidant" title="Antioxidant">antioxidants</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87">[87]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Obesity" title="Obesity">Obesity</a>, a serious problem in the western world, leads to higher chances of developing <a href="/wiki/Heart_disease" title="Heart disease" class="mw-redirect">heart disease</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Diabetes&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Diabetes (page does not exist)">diabetes</a>, and many other diseases.<sup id="cite_ref-88" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-88">[88]</a></sup> More recently, dietary habits have been influenced by the concerns that some people have about possible impacts on health or the environment from <a href="/wiki/Genetically_modified_food" title="Genetically modified food">genetically modified food</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-89" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-89">[89]</a></sup> Further concerns about the impact of industrial farming (<a href="/wiki/Cereal" title="Cereal">grains</a>) on <a href="/wiki/Animal_welfare" title="Animal welfare">animal welfare</a>, human health, and the <a href="/wiki/Ecology" title="Ecology">environment</a> are also having an effect on contemporary human dietary habits. This has led to the emergence of a movement with a preference for <a href="/w/index.php?title=Organic_food&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Organic food (page does not exist)">organic</a> and <a href="/wiki/Local_food" title="Local food">local food</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-90" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-90">[90]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Nutrition_and_dietary_problems">Nutrition and dietary problems</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:USDA_MyPlate_green.jpg" title="File:USDA MyPlate green.jpg">File:USDA MyPlate green.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/w/index.php?title=MyPlate&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="MyPlate (page does not exist)">MyPlate</a> replaced <a href="/w/index.php?title=MyPyramid&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="MyPyramid (page does not exist)">MyPyramid</a> as the <a href="/w/index.php?title=USDA&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="USDA (page does not exist)">USDA</a> nutrition guide.</div></div></div>
<p>Between the extremes of optimal health and death from <a href="/wiki/Starvation" title="Starvation">starvation</a> or <a href="/wiki/Malnutrition" title="Malnutrition">malnutrition</a>, there is an array of disease states that can be caused or alleviated by changes in diet. Deficiencies, excesses, and imbalances in diet can produce negative impacts on health, which may lead to various health problems such as <a href="/wiki/Scurvy" title="Scurvy">scurvy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Obesity" title="Obesity">obesity</a>, or <a href="/wiki/Osteoporosis" title="Osteoporosis">osteoporosis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Diabetes_mellitus_type_2" title="Diabetes mellitus type 2">diabetes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cardiovascular_diseases" title="Cardiovascular diseases" class="mw-redirect">cardiovascular diseases</a> as well as psychological and behavioral problems. The science of nutrition attempts to understand how and why specific dietary aspects influence health.
</p><p>Nutrients in food are grouped into several categories. Macronutrients are fat, protein, and carbohydrates. Micronutrients are the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dietary_mineral&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dietary mineral (page does not exist)">minerals</a> and <a href="/wiki/Vitamins" title="Vitamins" class="mw-redirect">vitamins</a>. Additionally, food contains water and <a href="/wiki/Dietary_fiber" title="Dietary fiber">dietary fiber</a>.
</p><p>As previously discussed, the body is designed by <a href="/wiki/Natural_selection" title="Natural selection">natural selection</a> to enjoy sweet and fattening foods for evolutionary diets, ideal for <a href="/wiki/Hunter-gatherer" title="Hunter-gatherer">hunters and gatherers</a>. Thus, sweet and fattening foods in nature are typically rare and are very pleasurable to eat. In modern times, with <a href="/wiki/Biotechnology" title="Biotechnology">advanced technology</a>, enjoyable foods are easily available to consumers. Unfortunately, this promotes <a href="/wiki/Obesity" title="Obesity">obesity</a> in adults and children alike.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Legal_definition">Legal definition</span></h2>
<p>Some countries list a legal definition of food. These countries list food as any item that is to be processed, partially processed, or unprocessed for consumption. The listing of items included as foodstuffs include any substance intended to be, or reasonably expected to be, ingested by <a href="/wiki/Human" title="Human">humans</a>. In addition to these foodstuffs, drink, <a href="/wiki/Chewing_gum" title="Chewing gum">chewing gum</a>, water, or other items processed into said food items are part of the legal definition of food. Items not included in the legal definition of food include <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pet_food&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pet food (page does not exist)">animal feed</a>, live animals (unless being prepared for sale in a market), plants prior to harvesting, medicinal products, <a href="/wiki/Cosmetics" title="Cosmetics">cosmetics</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tobacco" title="Tobacco">tobacco</a> and tobacco products, <a href="/wiki/Narcotic" title="Narcotic">narcotic</a> or <a href="/wiki/Psychotropic_substance" title="Psychotropic substance" class="mw-redirect">psychotropic substances</a>, and residues and contaminants.<sup id="cite_ref-91" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-91">[91]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Types_of_food">Types of food</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Div_col&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Div col (page does not exist)">Template:Div col</a>
</p>
<ul>
<li> <a href="/wiki/Comfort_food" title="Comfort food">Comfort food</a>
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/Fast_food" title="Fast food">Fast food</a>
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/Junk_food" title="Junk food">Junk food</a>
</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Natural_food&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Natural food (page does not exist)">Natural food</a>
</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Organic_food&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Organic food (page does not exist)">Organic food</a>
</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Slow_food&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Slow food (page does not exist)">Slow food</a>
</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Whole_food&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Whole food (page does not exist)">Whole food</a>
</li>
</ul>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Div_col_end&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Div col end (page does not exist)">Template:Div col end</a>
</p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Reflist&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Reflist (page does not exist)">Template:Reflist</a>
</p>

September 2000. <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/1583670165" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 1-58367-016-5</a>.

</li>
<li> Merson, Michael H.; Black, Robert E.; Mills, Anne J. <i>International Public Health: Disease, Programs, Systems, and Policies</i>. Jones and Bartlett Publishers, 2005.
</li>
<li> McGee, Harold. <i>On Food and Cooking: The Science and Lore of the Kitchen</i>. New York: Simon and Schuster, 2004. <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0684800012" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 0-684-80001-2</a>.
</li>
<li> Mead, Margaret.<i> The Changing Significance of Food</i>. In Carole Counihan and Penny Van Esterik (Ed.), Food and Culture: A Reader. UK: Routledge, 1997. <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0415917107" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 0-415-91710-7</a>.
</li>
<li> Messer, Ellen; Derose, Laurie Fields and Sara Millman. <i>Who's Hungry? and How Do We Know?: Food Shortage, Poverty, and Deprivation</i>. United Nations University Press, 1998. <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9280809857" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 92-808-0985-7</a>.
</li>
<li> National Institute of Health. <i>Food poisoning</i>. MedlinePlus Medical Encyclopedia F. May 11, 2006. Retrieved from <a rel="nofollow" class="external free" href="http://www.niaid.nih.gov/publications/pdf/foodallergy.pdf">http://www.niaid.nih.gov/publications/pdf/foodallergy.pdf</a> on 2006-09-29.
</li>
<li> Nicklas, Barbara J. <i>Endurance Exercise and Adipose Tissue</i>. CRC Press, 2002. <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0849304601" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 0-8493-0460-1</a>.
</li>
<li> Parekh, Sarad R. <i>The Gmo Handbook: Genetically Modified Animals, Microbes, and Plants in Biotechnology</i>. Humana Press,2004. <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/1588293076" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 1-58829-307-6</a>.
</li>
<li> Regmi, Anita (editor).<i>Changing Structure of Global Food Consumption and Trade</i>. Market and Trade Economics Division, Economic Research Service, USDA, May 30, 2001. stock #ERSWRS01-1.
</li>
<li> Schor, Juliet; Taylor, Betsy (editors). <i>Sustainable Planet: Roadmaps for the Twenty-First Century</i>. Beacon Press, 2003. <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0807004553" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 0-8070-0455-3</a>.
</li>
<li> Shah, Anup. <i>Food Dumping (Aid) Maintains Poverty. Causes of Poverty</i>. Retrieved from <a rel="nofollow" class="external free" href="http://www.globalissues.org/TradeRelated/Poverty/FoodDumping.asp">http://www.globalissues.org/TradeRelated/Poverty/FoodDumping.asp</a> on 2006-09-29.
</li>
<li> Simoons, Frederick J. <i>Eat Not This Flesh: Food Avoidances from Prehistory to the Present</i>. <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0299142507" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 0-299-14250-7</a>.
</li>
<li> Smith, Andrew (Editor). “Food Marketing,” in Oxford Encyclopedia of American Food and Drink, New York: Oxford University Press, 2007.
</li>
<li> The Economic Research Service of the USDA. <i>Global Food Markets: Briefing Rooms</i>. Retrieved from <a rel="nofollow" class="external free" href="http://www.ers.usda.gov/Briefing/">http://www.ers.usda.gov/Briefing/</a> on 2006-09-29.
</li>
<li> United Kingdom Office of Public Sector Information. <i>Food Safety Act 1990 (c. 16)</i>. Retrieved from <a rel="nofollow" class="external free" href="http://www.opsi.gov.uk/acts/acts1990/Ukpga_19900016_en_2.htm#mdiv1">http://www.opsi.gov.uk/acts/acts1990/Ukpga_19900016_en_2.htm#mdiv1</a> on 2006-11-08.
</li>
<li> United States Department of Agriculture, USDA Economic Research Service: The Economics of Food, Farming, Natural Resources, and Rural America. <i>"Briefing Rooms, Food CPI, Prices and Expenditures: Food Expenditure Tables"</i>. Retrieved from <a rel="nofollow" class="external free" href="http://www.ers.usda.gov/briefing/CPIFoodAndExpenditures/Data/">http://www.ers.usda.gov/briefing/CPIFoodAndExpenditures/Data/</a> on 2007-06-06.
</li>
<li> Van den Bossche, Peter. <i>The Law and Policy of the bosanac Trade Organization: Text, Cases and Materials</i>. UK: Cambridge University Press, 2005. <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0521822904" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 0-521-82290-4</a>.
</li>
<li> World Food Programme. <i>Breaking out of the Poverty Trap: How We Use Food Aid</i>. Retrieved from <a rel="nofollow" class="external free" href="http://www.wfp.org/food_aid/introduction/index.asp?section=12&amp;sub_section=1">http://www.wfp.org/food_aid/introduction/index.asp?section=12&amp;sub_section=1</a> on 2006-09-29.
</li>
<li> World Health Organization. <i>WHO Global Database on Child Growth and Malnutrition</i>.  Retrieved from <a rel="nofollow" class="external free" href="http://www.who.int/nutgrowthdb/en/">http://www.who.int/nutgrowthdb/en/</a> on 2006-09-29.
</li>
<li> World Trade Organization. <i>The Uruguay Round</i>.  Retrieved from <a rel="nofollow" class="external free" href="http://www.wto.org/trade_resources/history/wto/urug_round.htm">http://www.wto.org/trade_resources/history/wto/urug_round.htm</a> on 2006-09-29.
</li>
</ul>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Refend&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Refend (page does not exist)">Template:Refend</a>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Further_reading">Further reading</span></h2>
<ul>
<li> Collingham, E. M.:  <i>The Taste of War: World War Two and the Battle for Food</i> (2011)
</li>
<li> Katz, Solomon: <i>The Encyclopedia of Food and Culture</i>, (Scribner, 2003)
</li>
<li> Marion Nestle: <i>Food Politics: How the Food Industry Influences Nutrition and Health</i>, University Presses of California, revised and expanded edition 2007, <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0520254031" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 0-520-25403-1</a>
</li>
<li> Mobbs, Michael: <i>Sustainable Food</i> Sydney: NewSouth Publishing, 2012.  <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9781920705541" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 9781920705541</a>
</li>
</ul>
